t: Isaiah 22
The Valley of Vision
The*p oracle concerning the valley of vision. What*pn is the matter with you now, that you have all gone up to the housetops?
You*ln who were full of noise, You*ln boisterous town, you exultant city; Your*ln slain were not slain with the sword, Nor*ln did they die in battle.
All*ln your rulers have fled together, And*iln have been captured without the bow; All*ln of you who were found were taken captive together, Though*ln they had fled far away.
Therefore*ln I say, “Turn your eyes away from me, Let*ln me weep bitterly, Do*ln not try to comfort me concerning the destruction of the daughter of my people.”
For*ln the Lord God*s of hosts has a day of panic, subjugation and confusion In*ln the valley of vision, A*ln breaking down of walls And*ln a crying to the mountain.
Elam*ln took up the quiver With*ln the chariots, infantry and*i horsemen; And*ln Kir uncovered the shield.
Then*ln your choicest valleys were full of chariots, And*ln the horsemen took up fixed positions at the gate.
And*ln He removed the defense of Judah. In*ln that day you depended on the weapons of the house of the forest,
And*ln you saw that the breaches In*ln the wall*i of the city of David were many; And*ln you collected the waters of the lower pool.
Then*ln you counted the houses of Jerusalem And*ln tore down houses to fortify the wall.
And*ln you made a reservoir between the two walls For*ln the waters of the old pool. But*ln you did not depend on Him who made it, Nor*ln did you take into consideration Him who planned it long ago.
Therefore*ln in that day the Lord God*s of hosts called you*i to weeping, to wailing, To*ln shaving the head and to wearing sackcloth.
Instead,*ln there is gaiety and gladness, Killing*ln of cattle and slaughtering of sheep, Eating*ln of meat and drinking of wine: “Let*ln us eat and drink, for tomorrow we may die.”
But*ln the Lord*s of hosts revealed Himself to me, “Surely*ln this iniquity shall not be forgiven you Until*ln you die,” says the Lord God*s of hosts.
Thus*p says the Lord God*s of hosts, “Come,*pn go to this steward, To*ln Shebna, who is in charge of the royal*i household,

‘What*ln right do you have here, And*ln whom do you have here, That*ln you have hewn a tomb for yourself here, You*ln who hew a tomb on the height, You*ln who carve a resting place for yourself in the rock?
Behold,*ln the Lord*s is about to hurl you headlong, O man. And*ln He is about to grasp you firmly
And*iln roll you tightly like a ball, To*iln be*i cast*i into a vast country; There*ln you will die And*ln there your splendid chariots will be, You*ln shame of your master’s house.’
I*ln will depose you from your office, And*ln I will pull you down from your station.
Then*ln it will come about in that day, That*ln I will summon My servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah,

And*ln I will clothe him with your tunic And*ln tie your sash securely about him. I*ln will entrust him with your authority, And*ln he will become a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
Then*ln I will set the key of the house of David on his shoulder, When*ln he opens no one will shut, When*ln he shuts no one will open.
I*ln will drive him like*i a peg in a firm place, And*ln he will become a throne of glory to his father’s house.
So*p they will hang on him all the glory of his father’s house, offspring and issue, all the least of vessels, from bowls to all the jars.
In that day,” declares the Lord*s of hosts, “the peg driven in a firm place will give way; it will even break off and fall, and the load hanging on it will be cut off, for the Lord*s has spoken.”
